comments.content: If j ranges from 1 to n_i where n_i = 3 when i = 2, why aren't the subscripts for s {1, 2, 3} respectively? Shouldn't it be {1, 2, 3} instead of {1, 4, 5}?
comments.document: If j ranges from 1 to n_i where n_i = 3 when i = 2, why aren't the subscripts for s {1, 2, 3} respectively? Shouldn't it be {1, 2, 3} instead of {1, 4, 5}?

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>I believe they've used the variable $j$ sort of arbitrarily, as a counter that counts iterations over the set $N_i$, but not referring to the <italic>actual</italic> node $j$ (I found this kinda weird, too). The solution is correct, each node should receive messages from only its neighbors (e.g. {1, 4, 5} for node 2). </paragraph><paragraph/></document>
comments.document: I believe they've used the variable $j$ sort of arbitrarily, as a counter that counts iterations over the set $N_i$, but not referring to the actual node $j$ (I found this kinda weird, too). The solution is correct, each node should receive messages from only its neighbors (e.g. {1, 4, 5} for node 2).

comments.content: Yeah I guess I'm being more picky, but the way the formulation is setup above, $j$ is an index, meaning $m_{i,j}$, is the neighbor number $j$ of node $i$. This kind of implies that the answer should have indexed answers for $s_i$ that index in the $N_i$ set, and not the actual nodes themselves. I understand the solution and it is indeed correct, I'm just being picky about a small detail. Thanks Athul.
comments.document: Yeah I guess I'm being more picky, but the way the formulation is setup above, $j$ is an index, meaning $m_{i,j}$, is the neighbor number $j$ of node $i$. This kind of implies that the answer should have indexed answers for $s_i$ that index in the $N_i$ set, and not the actual nodes themselves.
